docs.lead_paragraph: When a bitterly divided Congress failed to pass an economic stimulus bill last fall, many predicted the recession would only worsen. But while few were paying attention, government spending surpassed the amounts envisioned in the stimulus measure, exceeding what even the most vociferous advocates wanted. The unexpected surge -- along with the remarkable strength in consumer spending -- helps to explain why the recession, to nearly everyone's surprise, has been so mild and may be ending.

headline.main: Sharp Rise in Federal Spending May Have Helped Ease Recession

docs.abstract: Unexpected surge in government spending--along with remarkable strength in consumer spending--helps to explain why recession in US has been been so mild and may be ending; surge in government spending, which started in October, has continued into March at rate of more than $100 billion; income tax cuts that went into effect at beginning of this year are expected to provide further lift to economy; photo; chart (L)
docs.snippet: When a bitterly divided Congress failed to pass an economic stimulus bill last fall, many predicted the recession would only worsen. But while few were paying attention, government spending surpassed the amounts envisioned in the stimulus measure,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Home Equity Lender to Pay $60 Million in Settlement First Alliance Mortgage, the home equity lender, has agreed to pay as much as $60 million to 18,000 people it is accused of deceiving by concealing high fees and interest rates that rose over time. The company would pay as much as $3,300 to each customer. The settlement is the largest reached by the Federal Trade Commission in a case involving predatory lending. Lawyers said the agreement would serve as a warning to other aggressive lenders and to the Wall Street bankers that finance them. [Page A1.]
docs.snippet: Home Equity Lender to Pay $60 Million in Settlement  First Alliance Mortgage, the home equity lender, has agreed to pay as much as $60 million to 18,000 people it is accused of deceiving by concealing high fees and interest rates that rose over time....

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Many Doctors Shun Patients With Medicare'' (front page, March 19) exposes a growing threat to our ability to provide quality care for older Americans. Physicians want to care for our nation's elderly, but too many are finding the financial losses unsustainable. Physicians face Medicare payment cuts of nearly 20 percent over four years. At the same time, they are dealing with sharp increases in their practice expenses, including skyrocketing liability insurance premiums in many states.
docs.abstract: American Medical Association chairman Dr Timothy T Flaherty letter on Mar 19 article backs bill to reverse Medicare payment cuts and fix flawed payment system

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration today proposed dropping a requirement at the heart of federal rules that protect the privacy of medical records. It said doctors and hospitals should not have to obtain consent from patients before using or disclosing medical information for the purpose of treatment or reimbursement. The proposal, favored by the health care industry, was announced by Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, who said the process of obtaining consent could have ''serious unintended consequences'' and could impair access to quality health care.

headline.main: BUSH ACTS TO DROP CORE PRIVACY RULE ON MEDICAL DATA

docs.abstract: Bush administration proposes dropping requirement at heart of federal rules protecting privacy of medical records; says doctors and hospitals should not have to obtain consent from patients before using or disclosing medical information for purpose of treatment or reimbursement; privacy rules were issued by Pres Bill Clinton in Dec 2000 and allowed to take effect last April by Pres Bush, to dismay of health care industry; hospitals and insurance companies claim consent requirement could delay health care; they praise administration's proposal as victory for common sense; consumer advocates and Democratic members of Congress denounce it as threat to privacy; proposal will be published in Federal Register, with 30 days for public comment; government will consider comments and issue final rule, with force of law (M)
docs.snippet: The Bush administration today proposed dropping a requirement at the heart of federal rules that protect the privacy of medical records. It said doctors and hospitals should not have to obtain consent from patients before using or disclosing medical...

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Jerusalem Bombing Kills 3, Shaking U.S. Peace Effort A Palestinian suicide bomber killed three Israelis in Jerusalem, prompting Israel to cancel truce talks. The Bush administration added the group that took responsibility, the Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades, to its list of terror groups, and officials said it was unlikely that Vice President Dick Cheney would meet with Yasir Arafat next week. Secretary of State Colin L. Powell demanded that Mr. Arafat condemn the bombing publicly both in English and Arabic. A1 Peru Blast Won't Deter Bush President Bush said that he intended to visit Peru tomorrow despite a car bombing outside the American Embassy on Wednesday that killed 9 Peruvians and injured 30. A3

docs.lead_paragraph: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 10. Now Playing ''ALL ABOUT THE BENJAMINS,'' starring Ice Cube and Mike Epps. Directed by Kevin Bray (R, 99 minutes). In this fast, violent caper comedy, Ice Cube and Mr. Epps reprise the hip-hop-era, Martin-and-Lewis routing they inaugurated in ''Next Friday.'' There are some funny bits and a few stylish action sequences as the pair, playing a roughneck bounty hunter (Ice Cube) and a motormouth petty con man (Mr. Epps), chase after stolen diamonds, a winning lottery ticket and an international cast of bad guys. But the light comic tone is marred by gruesome, sadistic violence, and the rabid materialism suggested by the title (which refers to $100 bills) has an ugly, cynical edge (A. O. Scott).

docs.lead_paragraph: It has long been known that blacks, Hispanics and other minorities receive lower-quality health care than whites do, a disparity generally attributed to lower incomes, inadequate insurance coverage and lack of doctors in minority areas. These socioeconomic causes are real, but a disturbing new study by the Institute of Medicine has concluded that even when members of minority groups have the same incomes, insurance coverage and medical conditions as whites, they receive notably poorer care. Biases, prejudices and negative racial stereotypes, the panel concludes, may be misleading doctors and other health professionals. The institute's 562-page report, which was requested by Congress, reviewed more than 100 studies that documented a wide range of disparities in medical care. Members of minorities were found less likely than whites to be given appropriate cardiac medicines or undergo coronary bypass surgery. They are less likely to receive kidney dialysis or kidney transplants or the best diagnostic tests and treatments for cancer. They are also less apt to receive the most sophisticated treatments for H.I.V., which can forestall the onset of AIDS.
docs.abstract: Editorial expresses alarm at study by Institute of Medicine concludes that members of minority groups receive notably poorer health care even when they have same incomes, insurance coverage and medical conditions as whites; says unconscious racism is as damaging as more overt forms of bigotry, and only lasting cure will be greater awareness and education for medical profession
docs.snippet: It has long been known that blacks, Hispanics and other minorities receive lower-quality health care than whites do, a disparity generally attributed to lower incomes, inadequate insurance coverage and lack of doctors in minority areas. These...

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors in the New York area face sharp increases in their medical malpractice insurance costs, which are already among the highest in the country. Insurance rate increases, most of them ranging from 10 to 40 percent, are already taking effect in New Jersey and Connecticut. In New York State, a majority of doctors are likely to pay at least 20 percent more in premiums over the next year. Those premiums are already substantial; for obstetricians and neurosurgeons, they can run to more than $100,000 annually.

headline.main: Doctors Face A Big Jump In Insurance
